header.title: The Hammer of Witches: A Complete Translation of the Malleus Maleficarum
header.category: Western Esotericism, Witchcraft Studies, Historical Demonology, Legal History

central_thesis: The text, the 'Malleus Maleficarum', systematically argues for the reality and extreme danger of sorcery as a diabolical heresy (satanism/diabolism), emphasizing a pact with the Devil. It provides a comprehensive theological and legal framework for its identification, prosecution, and extermination, portraying sorcery, particularly by women, as a major threat to Christendom requiring drastic judicial measures.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part I: Proof of the existence of sorcery
structure_content.summary: This part establishes the theological basis for the reality of sorcery, its demonic origin, and divine permission, refuting opposing views and detailing various acts attributed to sorceresses.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 1: Whether claiming that sorcerers exist is such a Catholic proposition that to defend the opposite view steadfastly is altogether heretical.
structure_content.summary: Establishes sorcery's reality as a heresy, refutes arguments denying it by asserting demonic co-operation and God's permission, and connects it to theological and civil law.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 2: Whether it is a Catholic proposition to claim that in order to achieve an effect of sorcery the demon always has to co-operate with a sorcerer, or that one without the other (the demon without a sorcerer or the other way around) can produce such an effect.
structure_content.summary: Explains the necessary co-operation between demons and sorcerers to achieve effects, refuting views that attribute effects solely to natural causes or human imagination, and outlines the role of divine permission.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 3: That it is a Catholic proposition to claim that humans can be begotten by incubus and succubus demons.
structure_content.summary: Argues for the possibility of human procreation through incubus and succubus demons, framing it as a Catholic proposition and discussing the mechanics of seed transfer and demonic interaction.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 4: (It is a Catholic proposition to claim that the acts of incubus and succubus demons are appropriate for all unclean spirits equally and without distinction).
structure_content.summary: Distinguishes between ranks of demons, asserting that lower-ranking demons are delegated for "filthy acts" like those involving incubi/succubi.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 5: Whether a Catholic can in any way hold the view that the origin and increase in number of sorcerers’ works derive from the influences of the heavenly bodies or from the superabundant evil of humans, and not from the filthy acts of incubus and succubus demons.
structure_content.summary: Refutes astrological or human-evil explanations for sorcery, firmly attributing its origin and increase to demonic influence and the sexual acts of incubi/succubi, contextualized within God's permission.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 6: Why a larger number of sorcerers is found among the delicate female sex than among men; what sort of women are more often to be found to be superstitious and sorceresses.
structure_content.summary: Explores the reasons why women are supposedly more prone to sorcery, citing inherent female defects (lack of faith, ambition, debauchery) and providing illustrations.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 7: Whether sorceresses can turn the minds of men to love or hatred.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the ability of sorceresses, with demonic aid, to influence human emotions, particularly love and hatred, by impelling the imagination and darkening the intellect.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 8: Whether sorceresses can impede the faculty to procreate.
structure_content.summary: Explains how sorceresses, through demonic assistance, can cause impotence or infertility by both internal and external means, noting God's permission for such acts.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 9: Whether sorceresses work on male members through the illusion of conjuring as if these limbs were completely pulled out of the body.
structure_content.summary: Addresses the phenomenon of seemingly removed male members, attributing it to demonic illusion and conjuring rather than real physical alteration, with practical anecdotes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 10: Whether sorceresses work on humans by turning them into the shapes of wild beasts through the art of conjuring.
structure_content.summary: Explains human transformation into beasts as a demonic illusion affecting the senses, distinguishing it from real physical change, and provides supporting anecdotes.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 11: That in various ways midwife sorceresses kill the fetuses in the womb and cause miscarriages, and when they do not do this, they offer the new-borns to demons.
structure_content.summary: Describes the horrific acts of midwife sorceresses in killing infants or offering them to demons, framing these as contributing to the increase of sorcery and divine wrath.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 12: Whether the endorsement of divine permission in connection with these works on the part of sorcerers is so Catholic a proposition that the opposite view (rejection of such permission) is altogether heretical.
structure_content.summary: Affirms that God's permission is necessary for sorcery to occur, refuting arguments that deny this or imply God's hostility, and explaining it through the concept of divine providence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 13: The two forms of divine permission justly granted by God, as a result of which the works of sorcerers are justly permitted, namely the Devil’s sinning as the originator of every evil and also the fall of the First Ancestors.
structure_content.summary: Explains God's permission for sorcery as a consequence of the sins of fallen angels and the First Ancestors, demonstrating how evil serves divine justice and glory.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 14: Whether the criminal deeds of the sorcerers surpass all the evil things that God permits and has permitted to happen from the beginning of the world until the present day both in terms of instances of guilt and penalties and losses.
structure_content.summary: Argues that the sins of sorceresses are more heinous than those of fallen angels or Adam, due to their explicit pacts and active renunciation of faith, leading to greater divine offense.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 15: That on account of the sins of sorceresses, innocent people are often affected by sorcery, though sometimes this is also because of their own sins.
structure_content.summary: Explains why innocent people suffer from sorcery, attributing it to divine punishment for others' sins (including sorceresses' actions) or the victims' own minor transgressions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 16: The foregoing truth is specifically explained by comparing the works of sorceresses to other varieties of superstition.
structure_content.summary: Delineates various forms of divination and superstition, asserting that sorcery (especially of women) surpasses them in vileness due to its explicit demonic pacts and active malice.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 17: Explanation of the fourteenth, comparing the seriousness of the crime to any sins on the part of demons.
structure_content.summary: Further elaborates on the superior heinousness of sorceresses' crimes compared to demons' sins, focusing on the willful renunciation of faith and continued malice after baptism.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 18: The method of preaching against the five arguments of laymen, by which various among them imagine that they prove that God does not permit such power to the Devil and sorceresses in connection with inflicting such acts of sorcery.
structure_content.summary: Provides counterarguments for preachers against laymen who deny God's permission for sorcery, emphasizing divine justice, human free will, and the role of evil in God's plan.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part II: The practice of inflicting and curing forms of sorcery
structure_content.summary: This part details the specific practices of sorceresses in inflicting harm and describes the various lawful and unlawful remedies against such acts, focusing on ecclesiastical interventions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introductory Question: Whether someone can be so benefited by good angels that he cannot be affected with sorcery by sorceresses in any of the methods described below.
structure_content.summary: Discusses divine protection against sorcery through good angels and certain Church rituals (Holy Water, Sign of the Cross), identifying those who are immune and the reasons for their immunity (public justice, faith, angelic guard).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 1: The different methods by which demons allure and entice the innocent through sorceresses to increase this form of breaking the Faith.
structure_content.summary: Explains how demons use sorceresses to entice innocent individuals into heresy, often starting with trivial matters and escalating to renunciation of faith, frequently targeting young women.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 2: The method of making a sacrilegious avowal.
structure_content.summary: Details the varied methods of sacrilegious avowal to demons, both ceremonial and private, including renouncing Christian faith, pledging allegiance, and using pastes made from unbaptized children.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 3: The method by which they are transferred in location from place to place.
structure_content.summary: Explores the bodily transportation of sorceresses by demons, clarifying that it can be both real and illusory, and discussing the demonic mechanics involved, often with the use of pastes from children.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 4: The method by which they subordinate themselves to incubus demons.
structure_content.summary: Describes the subordination of sorceresses to incubus demons for carnal acts, emphasizing the demons' motives (not pleasure, but corruption and increasing their numbers) and the ways these acts are performed.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 5: The general way in which sorceresses practice their acts of sorcery through the Sacraments of the Church and on the way in which they impede the force of procreation or produce any other defects in any creations, except for the heavenly bodies.
structure_content.summary: Outlines how sorceresses use sacrilegious acts against Church Sacraments and Sacramentals to inflict harm, particularly impeding procreation in humans and animals, and causing other defects with God's permission.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 6: The method by which they impede the force of procreation.
structure_content.summary: Details specific methods used by sorceresses to impede procreation in humans and animals, both internally and externally, often using objects like snakes and plants, with God's permission due to the original sin.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 7: The way in which they take away male members.
structure_content.summary: Explains the illusion of male members being "taken away" by sorceresses through conjuring, which deceives the senses but is not a physical removal, and relates anecdotes of such occurrences and their "restoration".

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 8: The methods by which they change humans into the shapes of wild beasts.
structure_content.summary: Clarifies that transformations into wild beasts are illusions affecting human perception (imagination and external senses), not true changes in substance, achieved by demons with God's permission.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 9: How demons exist inside bodies and heads without causing harm when they work changes involving conjuring.
structure_content.summary: Discusses how demons can operate within human bodies and minds (specifically the head and internal faculties) to create illusions of transformation without causing physical pain, by manipulating stored images.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 10: The method by which demons sometimes inhabit humans in substance through the workings of sorceresses.
structure_content.summary: Describes how demons can possess humans in substance, often at the insistence of sorceresses, for various reasons (merit, venial sin, serious sin, great crime), and the different ways possession manifests.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 11: The method by which they can inflict every kind of illness (in general terms about the more serious illnesses).
structure_content.summary: Asserts that sorceresses, with demonic aid, can inflict all kinds of bodily illnesses, including leprosy and epilepsy, through specific methods and devices (e.g., hidden objects).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 12: The method by which they inflict other quite similar illnesses in particular on humans.
structure_content.summary: Provides specific anecdotes of sorceresses inflicting particular illnesses on humans (e.g., headaches, leprosy) through various magical acts and demonic co-operation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 13: The method by which midwife sorceresses inflict greater losses when they either kill babies or offer them to demons by dedicating them with a curse.
structure_content.summary: Elaborates on the grave crimes of midwife sorceresses, who kill unbaptized infants or offer them to demons, explaining the demonic motivations (postponing Final Judgment) and methods used (pastes from children).

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 14: The method by which sorceresses inflict various forms of harm on domestic animals.
structure_content.summary: Describes how sorceresses inflict harm on domestic animals, such as depriving cows of milk or killing them, often through hidden devices or specific invocations, with God's permission.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 15: The method by which they stir up hailstorms and rainstorms and also make lightning strike humans and domestic animals.
structure_content.summary: Explains how sorceresses, through demonic agency, can cause natural phenomena like hailstorms, rainstorms, and lightning strikes, using rituals such as offering black roosters or urinating into ditches.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapters 16–18: The three methods by which men and not women are found to be tainted with acts of sorcery.
structure_content.summary: Discusses male sorcerers, including archers who profane sacred images for protection, enchanters who use chants on weapons, and those who use written handbooks, categorizing them as apostates or heretics.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 2: Introductory Question: Whether it is lawful to remove acts of sorcery through other acts of sorcery or through other unlawful means.
structure_content.summary: Addresses the lawfulness of counteracting sorcery, distinguishing between unlawful (demonic aid) and lawful (Church remedies, true repentance) means, emphasizing that evil cannot be used to achieve good.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 1: Ecclesiastical remedy against incubus and succubus demons.
structure_content.summary: Details lawful ecclesiastical remedies against incubus and succubus harassment, including Sacramental Confession, Sign of the Cross, Holy Water, Hail Mary, exorcisms, and a change of place.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 2: Remedies for those who are affected with sorcery in the power of procreation.
structure_content.summary: Provides specific lawful remedies for sorcery affecting procreation, including pilgrimages, confession, devout prayer, exorcism, and the removal of sorcery devices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 3: Remedies for people affected by sorcery in terms of irregular love or hatred.
structure_content.summary: Outlines remedies for irregular love or hatred caused by sorcery or demonic temptation, emphasizing spiritual methods like confession, prayer, and shunning the object of obsession.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 4: Remedies for those from whom the male member has been removed through the magical art and for the instances when humans are transformed into animals.
structure_content.summary: Discusses remedies for illusory male member removal and transformation into animals, focusing on true confession, reconciliation with God, and discerning illusions from reality.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 5: Remedies for those under siege as a result of sorcery.
structure_content.summary: Describes remedies for demonic possession (siege) due to sorcery, emphasizing Holy Communion, holy places, devout prayers, and absolution from excommunication.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 6: Remedies through lawful exorcisms of the Church against any illnesses inflicted by sorceresses, and the method of exorcizing people affected by sorcery.
structure_content.summary: Details the lawful methods of Church exorcism to cure illnesses inflicted by sorcery, including the seven conditions for lawful blessings and chants, and the procedures for exorcizing individuals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 7: Remedies against hailstorms and for domestic animals affected by sorcery.
structure_content.summary: Explains lawful and unlawful remedies against hailstorms and sorcery affecting domestic animals, emphasizing prayers, the Sign of the Cross, and Holy Water over superstitious practices.

structure_content.chapter_title: Chapter 8: Certain hidden remedies against certain hidden vexations on the part of demons.
structure_content.summary: Discusses remedies for "changelings" (children substituted by demons) and other hidden demonic vexations, attributing them to divine permission and linking them to excessive parental love or superstition.

structure_content.chapter_title: Part III: Judicial extermination of sorceresses
structure_content.summary: This part details the legal and judicial procedures for prosecuting, convicting, and punishing sorcerers and sorceresses, covering witness examination, torture, and various sentencing methods.

structure_content.chapter_title: Introductory Question: Whether sorcerers and those who abet, receive and defend them are subject in such a way to the ecclesiastical passing of judgment by diocesans and to the civil passing of judgment, that the inquisitors of heretical depravity can be relieved of conducting an inquisition into them.
structure_content.summary: Addresses the jurisdiction over sorcerers, arguing that both ecclesiastical and civil courts have authority, and that inquisitors should focus on prosecuting heresy, leaving general sorcery to bishops and secular judges.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 1: The method of initiating the proceedings.
structure_content.summary: Details three methods of initiating legal proceedings against sorceresses: accusation, denunciation, and inquisition (most common), emphasizing the judge's role and the need for thorough examination of witnesses.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 2: The number of witnesses.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the number and reliability of witnesses required for condemnation, arguing that while two witnesses are legally sufficient, three concordant witnesses are preferred for heresy charges due to their gravity.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 3: Whether they can be forced to give an oath.
structure_content.summary: Affirms that witnesses can be compelled to swear an oath to tell the truth and can be re-examined multiple times, especially in ecclesiastical cases involving heresy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 4: The status of the witnesses.
structure_content.summary: Specifies who is allowed to give testimony against sorcerers, including excommunicates, infamous persons, criminals, and family members, due to the gravity of heresy charges.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 5: Whether mortal enemies are allowed to give testimony.
structure_content.summary: Explains that mortal enemies are generally debarred from testifying, but other enmities may weaken testimony; the judge must investigate enmity carefully and discern bias.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 6: How the proceedings are to be continued: how the witnesses are to be examined in the presence of four other persons, and the two ways in which the denounced woman is to be questioned.
structure_content.summary: Outlines the informal, summary nature of heresy proceedings, emphasizing the need for five persons present during witness examination and the methods of questioning the accused (general and specific questions).

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 7: Various doubts are explained about the previous lists of questions and negative answers, whether the denounced woman should be imprisoned, and when she should be considered to be manifestly caught in the Heresy of Sorceresses.
structure_content.summary: Addresses the criteria for declaring a woman "manifestly caught" in sorcery (bad reputation, indications of deed, witness testimony) and the justification for her imprisonment and continued questioning.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 8: Whether she should be imprisoned and the method of arrest.
structure_content.summary: Details the procedures for arresting and imprisoning suspects, including searching their homes for sorcery devices and the various methods used to carry suspects to prevent "sorcery of silence".

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 9: What should be done after the arrest and whether the names of those giving depositions should be made known to her.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the advocate's role, the suppression of witness names for their safety, and stratagems to elicit confessions by revealing specific accusations without identifying accusers.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 10: How lines of defense are to be granted along with the assignment of an advocate.
structure_content.summary: Outlines the procedures for assigning an advocate, who is given the protocol with suppressed names, and the advocate's duty to advise the accused truthfully, even if it means urging confession.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 11: What the advocate will do when the names of the witnesses are not revealed to him.
structure_content.summary: Instructs the advocate on how to proceed when witness names are withheld, by presenting the accused with specific details of depositions to elicit a response or an allegation of enmity.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 12: Further explanation of how mortal enmity is to be investigated.
structure_content.summary: Describes methods for a judge to investigate claims of mortal enmity, using strategies like presenting fragmented testimony to obscure witness identity and determine the veracity of enmity claims.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 13: (Omitted issue of demand by the accused that the judge recuse himself).
structure_content.summary: This question was omitted from the text's outline.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 14: The things that the judge has to consider before setting out the list of questions in the prison and torture chamber.
structure_content.summary: Guides the judge on considerations before applying torture, emphasizing that it should only be used after other proofs fail, and advising a cautious approach due to the "sorcery of silence".

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 15: The continuation of the torture and the stratagems and signs by which the judge can recognize a sorceress, and how he ought to forearm himself against their acts of sorcery, and how they should be shaved, and the situation where they have hidden devices for sorcery, along with various explanations of how to block the sorcery of silence.
structure_content.summary: Details methods for continuing torture, recognizing sorceresses (e.g., inability to cry, hidden amulets), and counteracting the "sorcery of silence" through shaving the body and using blessed objects or rituals.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 16: The time and second method of questioning.
structure_content.summary: Discusses the timing of questioning (holy days, Mass times) and methods to prepare the accused (blessed objects, Holy Water, Scripture readings) to encourage confession under torture.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 17: The vulgar form of purgation, and especially the examination by glowing iron, to which sorceresses appeal.
structure_content.summary: Explains the unlawfulness of "vulgar purgation" (ordeals by glowing iron) for proving innocence in sorcery cases, arguing it tempts God and is not sanctioned by Church authority.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 18: The definitive sentence as such and how it should be passed.
structure_content.summary: Outlines the general principles for passing definitive sentences, distinguishing between interlocutory and definitive judgments and the procedural requirements for a valid sentence.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 19: How many methods create a suspicion that results in the passing of sentence.
structure_content.summary: Describes the different levels of suspicion (light, vehement, violent) that justify various sentences, based on evidence, reputation, and the accused's actions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 20: The method of passing sentence.
structure_content.summary: Details the method of passing sentence for a person found innocent but denounced, resulting in total absolution, emphasizing that innocence is declared only if nothing is legally proven.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 21: The method of sentencing a denounced woman who merely has a bad reputation.
structure_content.summary: Explains the method of sentencing for a denounced person with only a bad reputation for heresy, involving canonical purgation and a public abjuration.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 22: The method of passing sentence on a woman with a bad reputation who is to be exposed to questioning under torture.
structure_content.summary: Outlines sentencing for a person with bad reputation and inconsistencies, leading to questioning under moderate torture, with the goal of eliciting a confession.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 23: The method of passing sentence on a denounced woman who is lightly suspected.
structure_content.summary: Describes sentencing for a lightly suspected person, involving public abjuration of heresy and penance, with the consequence of harsher punishment if they relapse.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 24: The method of passing sentence on a woman vehemently suspected.
structure_content.summary: Explains sentencing for a vehemently suspected person, requiring a public abjuration of all heresy, with the understanding that relapse leads to the death penalty.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 25: The method of passing sentence on a denounced woman who is violently suspected.
structure_content.summary: Details sentencing for a violently suspected person, who is considered a heretic and must abjure heresy; if they persist in denial, they are handed over to the secular arm.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 26: The method of passing sentence on a denounced woman who is suspected and has a bad reputation.
structure_content.summary: Describes sentencing for a person both suspected and with a bad reputation, involving public canonical purgation and abjuration, with prescribed penances.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 27: The method of passing sentence on a woman who has confessed heresy but is penitent.
structure_content.summary: Outlines sentencing for a penitent heretic who has confessed but not relapsed, involving life imprisonment and a public confession of crimes, with a focus on spiritual conversion.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 28: The method of passing sentence on a woman who has confessed heresy but is relapsed, though repentant.
structure_content.summary: Explains sentencing for a repentant but relapsed heretic, who, despite repentance, is handed over to the secular arm for the death penalty, emphasizing spiritual preparation.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 29: The method of passing sentence on a woman who has confessed heresy but is impenitent and yet not relapsed.
structure_content.summary: Describes sentencing for an impenitent but not relapsed heretic, involving prolonged imprisonment and attempts to induce conversion; if persistent, handed to the secular arm for death.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 30: The woman who has confessed heresy and relapsed and is impenitent.
structure_content.summary: Outlines sentencing for an impenitent and relapsed heretic, who is condemned as such and immediately abandoned to the secular arm for execution, with no further mercy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 31: The person who is convicted and caught, but denies everything.
structure_content.summary: Details sentencing for a person legally convicted by evidence or witnesses but denying everything, involving harsh imprisonment, repeated warnings, and eventual handover to the secular arm for death.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 32: The person who is convicted but who is a fugitive or contumaciously absents himself.
structure_content.summary: Describes sentencing for a convicted fugitive or one who contumaciously absents himself, involving excommunication, public denunciation, and eventual condemnation as an obstinate heretic, leading to secular execution.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 33: How to pass sentence on a person denounced by another sorceress who has been or is to be burned to ashes.
structure_content.summary: Outlines sentencing for a person denounced by a convicted sorceress, distinguishing based on additional evidence and reputation, leading to absolution, canonical purgation, or torture.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 34: The method of passing sentence on a sorceress who breaks acts of sorcery, and on sorceress midwives and sorcerer archers.
structure_content.summary: Addresses sentencing for sorceresses who break acts of sorcery (healers), midwife sorceresses, and male sorcerer archers, categorizing their acts as unlawful superstition or heresy.

structure_content.chapter_title: Question 35: The methods of sentencing any sorcerers who lodge frivolous or unjust appeals.
structure_content.summary: Details the judge's procedures for handling frivolous or unjust appeals from accused sorcerers, rejecting groundless appeals and continuing the legal process.

key_concepts.definition: Best known treatise on witchcraft from the early modern period, published 1486, popularizing satanism/diabolism, instrumental in 'witch craze'.
Malevolent magic, specifically the infliction of evil acts, linked to a pact with the Devil. The Latin term maleficus (evil-doer) is used.

New conception of magic/witchcraft involving a pact with the Devil, sexual relations with demons, aerial flight to assemblies presided over by Satan, practice of maleficent magic, and slaughter of babies.

A scholarly term for the new notion of sorcery characterized by six basic beliefs: pact with Devil, sexual relations with Devil, aerial flight, assembly with Satan, maleficent magic, slaughter of babies.
Ecclesiastical institution arising in 13th century to combat heresy, appointing mendicant friars (Dominicans) as inquisitors.

Standard scholastic argumentation method (used in Part I), beginning with a title, presenting arguments for a false answer, contradictory evidence, a 'determination' (body), and refutations of initial arguments.
A charge (like sorcery) exempted from usual legal precautions, allowing extreme measures like torture.
A supposed ability of sorceresses to become immune to pain under torture, preventing confession, which inquisitors sought to counteract.
Rejection of the Christian faith adopted at baptism, especially through sacrilegious speech and homage to Satan.
Holding opinions contrary to Catholic Faith, especially with an obstinate will. Sorcery is framed as a form of heresy.
Male/female demons engaging in sexual relations with humans, used by the Devil to increase the number of sorcerers and taint progeny.
Ecclesiastical observances not formal sacraments but considered analogous, e.g., holy water, Sign of the Cross.
A legal procedure where a person with a bad reputation for heresy must clear themselves under oath with compurgators.
A formal denial under oath of heresy, usually public, imposed on suspects.
One who returns to heresy after abjuring it, subject to the death penalty.

practical_system.description: The 'Malleus Maleficarum' outlines a punitive system for identifying, prosecuting, and exterminating individuals accused of sorcery, framed as a diabolical heresy. It details the perceived mechanics of demonic influence, sorceresses' actions, and God's permission, establishing a legal framework for inquisitors and secular judges rather than a magical practice.
tools: Pastes from children's limbs (attributed to sorceresses)
Hidden devices (snake parts, bones, kernels) (attributed to sorceresses)
Milk pitchers (for stealing milk) (attributed to sorceresses)
rituals: Pledging homage to the Devil (by sorceresses)
Sexual relations with incubus/succubus demons (by sorceresses)
Offering unbaptized babies to demons (by sorceresses)
Stirring up storms (e.g., urinating into ditches, sacrificing black roosters) (attributed to sorceresses)
Inflicting illnesses and impotence (attributed to sorceresses)
Creating illusions of transformation (attributed to sorceresses)
Exorcisms through prayers and Holy Words (by inquisitors)
Shaving the accused's body to remove hidden sorcery devices (by inquisitors)

relevant_quotes.text: The Malleus Maleficarum, first published in 1486, is the standard medieval text on witchcraft and it remained in print throughout the early modern period. Its descriptions of the evil acts of witches and the ways to exterminate them continue to contribute to our knowledge of early modern law, religion and society.

The present work offers the reader the only full and reliable translation of the Malleus into English, and this introduction has a very specific purpose: to set out for the reader the general intellectual and cultural background of the Malleus, which takes for granted and is based upon a number of concepts that are by no means self-evident to the average modern reader, and to explain some thing of the circumstances of the work’s composition and the authors’ methods and purposes in writing it.
The Malleus Maleficarum is thus a hammer to be used to smash the conspiracy of sorceresses that was thought to be threatening the very existence of Christendom (this belief is treated below).

The new conception of sorcery as a form of direct worship of Satan that involves the infliction of harm though sorcery can be derived from the revolting lies told about the heretical sect known as the Waldensians by their orthodox foes.

First, a matter of terminology. In the German text of the Nuremberg Handbook, Institoris uniformly uses the term Unhold for a 'witch' belonging to the 'Heresy of Sorceresses.'... the literal meaning of maleficus is 'evil-doer,' and it is the inherent necessity to inflict evil through sorcery that distinguishes adherents of the sect from mere dabblers in magic.

The great persecutions of sorcery that lasted from the fifteenth until the early seventeenth centuries were based upon a new notion of sorcery that can be termed 'satanism' (or 'diabolism'). This view saw the supposed 'witch' as participating in a malevolent society presided over by Satan himself and dedicated to the infliction of malevolent acts of sorcery (maleficia) on others.

The Malleus has been characterized as a thoroughly misogynistic work, and (to borrow a mode of argument from scholasticism) this is true or not depending on what one means by misogyny. In the proper meaning of the term, it signifies a self-conscious literary attack on the female gender as a whole. This genre of literature is exemplified in the Greek poet Semonides’ attack on women or the Sixth Satire of the Roman poet Juvenal. By this standard, the Malleus is not misogynistic in that even the main passage discussing what is taken to be the flawed nature of females is prefaced with an overt statement that the negative characterization of women as a group does not apply to all of them (42B), and the work contains references to pious women who resist the allurements of sorcery or fall victim to it.

critical_analysis.relevance: The 'Malleus Maleficarum' is historically significant as a foundational text for early modern witchcraft persecutions, providing insight into the demonological theories and judicial practices of the period. However, its 'practical system' is a punitive framework for identifying and prosecuting perceived sorcery, not a guide for practicing magic. It reveals the historical construction of 'witchcraft' as a heresy and the legal mechanisms used to combat it, rather than endorsing or teaching magical arts.
critical_analysis.target_audience: Historians, scholars of early modern law and religion, students of witchcraft studies, and academics interested in the intellectual and cultural context of demonological texts. It is not intended as a manual for modern magical practice due to its historical and punitive nature.
